keyTakeAways: Saying 'no' is essential to setting boundaries at work and preventing burnout.
The phrase 'I don't' is more effective than 'I can't' when setting boundaries because it is definitive and harder to challenge.
Burnout is not just a workplace issue for high earners or professionals — it affects anyone, especially women with family responsibilities.
Personal factors like perfectionism and childhood experiences (e.g., foster care) can contribute to burnout.
Burnout is defined by exhaustion, detachment, and reduced performance — not just feeling stressed.
Adjusting goals to one’s current capacity and prioritizing self-care are key to recovery.
Even in hierarchical workplaces, workers should speak up to their bosses to request changes in workload or boundaries.
Setting boundaries protects mental health and improves long-term productivity and well-being.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article emphasizes that saying 'no' at work is essential to prevent burnout, especially in high-pressure environments. It highlights the importance of using language such as 'I don't' instead of 'I can't' to set clear, unchallengable boundaries. Personal stories from career coach Helen Tupper, TV chef Lorraine Pascale, and psychiatrist Dr Claire Ashley illustrate how ambition, perfectionism, and family responsibilities can lead to physical and emotional burnout. Experts stress that recognizing individual capacity, adjusting goals, and establishing boundaries—even in hierarchical workplaces—are vital for mental well-being. The article concludes that burnout is not just a symptom of stress but a diagnosable condition involving exhaustion, detachment, and reduced performance, and that proactive self-care and boundary-setting are key to long-term resilience.
